title: Total and partial knee arthroplasty versus non-surgical interventions of the knee for moderate to severe osteoarthritis.
abstract: Total and partial knee arthroplasty (TKA, PKA) are common treatments for moderate to severe knee osteoarthritis. While effective in symptom management, these surgeries carry potential risks, necessitating careful evaluation of benefits and harms. High-quality evidence comparing TKA/PKA to placebo, sham, or non-surgical interventions is essential to support informed decision-making.
journal: The Cochrane database of systematic reviews
